newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugoslavian tourism down 7.0 pct in Jan-Sept.
newsitem.headline: Yugoslavian tourism down 7.0 pct in Jan-Sept.

text.p: Around 2.32 million tourists registered in Yugoslavia from January to September this year, or seven percent less than in the same period in 1995, the Federal Statistics Office said in a report on Wednesday.
Yugoslavs accounted for 2.09 million of the total, a drop of 10 percent against the January-September period last year.
Some 121,700 foreigners visited the country, an increase of 64.5 percent against the same period last year.
Most foreign tourists, or 15,347, came from the Russian Federation, followed by 12,450 from Italy, 10,037 from Greece, 9,045 from Bulgaria and 8,979 from Germany.
The number of Visitors from other republics of the former Yugoslavia -- Bosnia, Croatia, Macedonia and Slovenia -- rose 8.2 percent compared with last year to 109,900.

According to data from the National Bank of Yugoslavia, hard currency income from tourism in the January-August period was $26.4 million, which was 13.7 percent less than in the same eight-month period last year.
